DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: SABA, M. M. F.;SABA, M;Saba, Marcelo M. F.;Saba, Marcelo Magalhães Fares;SABA, MARCELO M.F.

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH:
Possui graduação em Física pela Universidade de São Paulo (1985), mestrado (1992) e doutorado (1997) em Geofísica Espacial pelo Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais. Atualmente é Pesquisador Titular III do Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais. Coordena projetos de pesquisa no Brasil e participou de vários projetos de pesquisa no exterior. É assessor científico da FAPESP e foi membro do Conselho Editorial da Revista Brasileira de Ensino de Física.
Iniciou o estudo sistemático de relâmpagos com câmeras de alta velocidade em 2003. Este estudo ainda vigente proporcionou o maior banco de vídeos de raios filmados em alta velocidade no mundo. Como resultado destas observações, importantes contribuições foram publicadas acerca das descargas atmosféricas.
Membro do Cigrè (International Council on Large Electric Systems) Working Group C4.407 - Lightning Parameters for Engineering Applications (grupo de 20 pesquisadores de diferentes países)
/ Chairman of the International Lightning Detection Conference/International Lightning Meteorology Conference
/ Vice-presidente do Conselho de Pós-graduação de Geofísica Espacial no INPE
/ Membro da Sociedade Brasileira de Física e da American Association of Physics Teachers.
/ Bolsa de Produtividade 2 do CNPq (2016-2019)
/ Índice H=15 (Scopus) H=13 (ISI).
Em 2011, teve um artigo entre os Top-50 mais citados nos últimos cinco anos na revista Atmospheric Research.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Graduate at Physics from Universidade de São Paulo (1985) Master's at Geophysics from Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (1992) Ph.D. at Geophysics from Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (1997). Has experience in Geosciences, acting on the following subjects: lightning, physics education Member of the Cigrè (International Council on Large Electric Systems) Working Group C4.407 - Lightning Parameters for Engineering Applications / Chairman of the International Lightning Detection Conference/International Lightning Meteorology Conference

OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES: A introdução do uso de câmeras de alta velocidade (câmeras rápidas) no estudo sistemático dos relâmpagos foi iniciado de modo pioneiro em 2003 pelo autor. Desde então milhares de raios negativos, positivos, e bipolares foram filmados em alta velocidade, constituindo o maior banco de dados de relâmpagos gravados em alta resolução temporal. Pela primeira vez observou no Brasil um raio ascendente. Atualmente temos um banco de dados de mais de 100 raios ascendentes filmados e analisados. Observou pela primeira vez no mundo com vídeo de alta velocidade a conexão entre um raio e um edifício residencial de altura comum (tema atual de estudo). Estes registros trouxeram grande avanço na compreensão do relâmpago e isto se traduziu em dissertações e teses, publicações em periódicos e capítulos de livros.

PARTICIPACAO-EM-PROJETO.NOME-ORGAO: Coordenação Geral de Ciências Espaciais e Atmosféricas

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Estudo das características dos raios através de imagens de alta resolução temporal
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Estudo das características dos raios através de imagens de alta resolução temporal
Objetivos: A - Conhecer caraterísticas importantes dos raios na região sudeste e levantar uma estatística dos seguintes parâmetros: 1. Duração total do raio 2. Número de descargas (multiplicidade) 3. Tempo entre descargas 4. Existência de corrente contínua e sua duração 5. Porcentagem de raios bifurcados 6. Estudo do líder escalonado
Dentre estes parâmetros, os itens 4 e 5 são de grande importância para os sistemas de proteção. A corrente contínua é uma corrente que persiste após a ocorrência da descarga e tem como conseqüência o aquecimento do meio por onde passa, sendo o principal fator destrutivo dos raios. Um raio pode ter várias descargas (multiplicidade) e em alguns casos atingir diferentes pontos no solo podendo ocasionando danos em mais de um local simultaneamente. Não existe nenhuma estatística sobre a porcentagem de raios bifurcados, e a utilização de uma câmara rápida para este fim é excelente, já que com resolução temporal entre quadros menor que 1 milisegundo, é possível registrar todas as descargas de um raio. Obs: câmaras de vídeo normais registram quadros a cada 33 milisegundos podendo perder várias descargas de um raio. Com este estudo poderemos ainda calcular pela primeira vez no país a velocidade e outros parâmetros do líder escalonado dos raios que é a seqüência de descargas que formam a trajetória do raio até o solo.
B - Verificar a eficiência de detecção e localização da rede de detecção de raios.
A câmara rápida é uma excelente ferramenta na aferição e na definição dos ajustes necessários para aumentar a eficiência das antenas utilizadas pela rede.

PARTICIPACAO-EM-PROJETO.NOME-UNIDADE: Coordenação de Ciências Espaciais e Atmosféricas

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Programa Nacional de Monitoramento de Raios - PRONAR
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: O objetivo geral deste projeto é o monitoramento através de diferentes técnicas da incidência de raios no Brasil, o estudo de suas características, e a disseminação desta informação para a sociedade. Tais atividades são de grande importância para o país, devido a grande incidência do fenômeno, estimada em cerca de 50 a 70 milhões de raios por ano, segunda última estimativa feita com base em análise comparativa de dados de satélite e de superfície. Ênfase será dada a novas descobertas científicas e seu impacto no desenvolvimento de inovações tecnológicas para minimizar os prejuízos dos raios sobre a sociedade. Serão utilizados sistemas de monitoramento em três faixas de freqüência diferentes: VLF, LF e VHF. Câmeras de vídeo de alta velocidade sincronizadas com GPS, torre instrumentada para medidas de corrente e foguetes para a indução de raios serão usados em várias campanhas para validar as informações obtidas pelos sistemas. As informações obtidas por estas técnicas também serão confrontadas com dados de satélites meteorológicos. O projeto será coordenado pelo Grupo de Eletricidade Atmosférica (ELAT) do Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais, em colaboração no Brasil com a Universidade Federal de Santa Catarina, a Universidade de São Paulo, a Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio Grande do Sul, a Universidade Federal do Mato Grosso do Sul e o Laboratório de Clima e Espaço de Santa Maria, nos Estados Unidos com a Universidade de Washington, e na Nova Zelândia com a Universidade de Dunedin. O projeto contará com o apoio do Centro de Previsão e Estudos Climáticos, do Centro Integrado de Meteorologia e Recursos Hídricos de Santa Catarina, do Centro Internacional de Pesquisas de Raios Induzidos, do Centro Tecnológico Aeroespacial, Sistema de Vigilância da Amazônia, do Sistema Meteorológico do Paraná, da Companhia Energética de Minas Gerais, de Furnas Centrais Elétricas, e da Empresa Transmissora de Energia Elétrica do Sul do Brasil.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Detecção de Sinais de Variabilidade relacionados a Mudanças Climáticas na Incidência e Características das Descargas Atmosféricas no Brasil
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Este projeto tem como objetivo a detecção de sinais de variabilidade relacionados a mudanças climáticas na incidência e características das descargas atmosféricas registradas no Brasil na última década e o aperfeiçoamento das atuais técnicas de observação de raios no estado de São Paulo de modo a permitir um melhor monitoramento destas variabilidades para o futuro

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: SABA, M. M. F.;SABA, M;Saba, Marcelo M. F.;Saba, Marcelo Magalhães Fares;SABA, MARCELO M.F.

FINANCIADOR-DO-PROJETO.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Características dos Raios Ascendentes no Brasil
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Até janeiro de 2012 nenhum raio ascendente havia sido registrado no Brasil. Com a ajuda de algumas câmeras registramos, durante os meses de janeiro, março e abril, quinze raios ascendentes que tiveram início a partir de uma ou mais torres situadas sobre o Pico do Jaraguá, na cidade de São Paulo. Este projeto de pesquisa visa caracterizar os raios ascendentes até então nunca observados e estudados no Brasil e pretende responder algumas questões que as primeiras e recentes observações suscitaram. Entre elas estão: Qual a frequência de tais descargas? Como se iniciam? Que tipo de estruturas são propícias para a sua iniciação? Quais os processos físicos que regem os raios ascendentes? Em que diferem dos raios descendentes extensivamente observados pelo grupo nos últimos anos? Em que diferem dos raios ascendentes observados em outros países? Para responder estas e outras questões descritas neste documento, combinaremos observações de câmeras de vídeo de alta resolução temporal, medidas de campo elétrico e dados de redes de detecção de relâmpagos. Prevemos ao longo do projeto três campanhas de observação de raios ascendentes. Duas delas para observação de raios ascendentes nas torres de comunicação situadas no Pico do Jaraguá e na Avenida Paulista (24 torres no total), e no arranha-céu Edifício Itália na cidade de São Paulo, e uma outra campanha patrocinada pela National Science Foundation (NSF) e pela Universidade do Arizona (Dept. of Atmospheric Sciences) para observação de raios ascendentes em uma fazenda de geradores eólicos no Kansas e torres de comunicação em South Dakota, EUA.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Up to January 2012, no upward flash had ever been registered in Brazil. With the help of some video cameras, we recorded during January, March and April, fifteen upward lightning which started from one or more towers located on Peak Jaraguá in the city of São Paulo. This research project aims to characterize upward lightning hitherto observed and studied in Brazil and aims to answer some questions that the early and recent observations have raised: What is the frequency of such discharges? How do they initiate? What kind of structures is favorable for their initiation? What physical processes rule them? How different they are from the downward lightning flashes extensively observed by the group in recent years? Are they different from upward lightning observed in other countries? How lightning locating systems installed in our country detect and locate them? To answer these and other questions in this document, we will combine observations of high temporal resolution video cameras, electric field measurements and data from lightning detection networks. The data collection will be done through three observation campaigns. Two of them to observe upward lightning from towers in Jaraguá Peak and Paulista Avenue (total of 23), and from the skyscraper Edifício Itália, a campaign sponsored by the National Science Foundation (NSF) and the University of Arizona (Dept. of Atmospheric Sciences) to observe upward lightning in a wind turbine farm towers in Kansas and from towers in South Dakota, USA. As the current lightning protection standards are based on downward flashes, this research intends to identify risks uniquely associated with upward lightning, which are not currently known and not even included in protection standards. As the ground contact of upward flashes is known this research will also help to improve the lightning locating systems that detect and monitor the incidence of lightning in Brazil.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Características dos Raios Ascendentes no Brasil

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Estudo da interação das descargas atmosféricas com as edificações
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: As descargas atmosféricas que atingem o solo (relâmpagos nuvem-solo) são responsáveis por imensos prejuízos materiais e por quase uma centena de óbitos anualmente no país. As normas que definem os sistemas de proteção contra descargas atmosféricas (SPDA) ainda se baseiam em métodos empíricos, modelos e teorias que carecem de dados provenientes de dados experimentais. Particularmente, o conhecimento das características do líder ascendente que parte das estruturas no solo na tentativa de conectar-se com o líder descendente de um relâmpago nuvem-solo é de crucial importância para a implementação de SPDAs mais eficazes. Este projeto tem como objetivo a caracterização dos líderes ascendentes. Também investigará qual a relação deles com os líderes descendentes e com as descargas de retorno que se originam no processo de conexão. Para alcançar este objetivo, além da análise de vídeos inéditos já obtidos por câmeras de alta velocidade, pretendemos analisar vídeos de líderes ascendentes com medidas simultâneas realizadas por outros sensores a serem instalados (campo elétrico e corrente elétrica). A análise conjunta destes dados servirá para caracterizar parâmetros importantes deste processo de conexão, como: a velocidade e a intensidade do líder ascendente; a razão entre as velocidades dos líderes descendentes e ascendentes; a distância de atração do SPDA e a sua relação com o pico de corrente da descarga; as características da descarga de conexão entre o líder ascendente e o descendente, etc. Este estudo poderá definir estes parâmetros pela primeira vez e assim ajudar na validação e melhoria de teorias e modelos usados na implementação de SPDAs em todo o mundo.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: SABA, M. M. F.;SABA, M;Saba, Marcelo M. F.;Saba, Marcelo Magalhães Fares;SABA, MARCELO M.F.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Projeto Eletrodinâmica das Tempestades associadas a Sprites
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: O projeto ETAS constitui-se em um projeto de colaboração entre o INPE, a Universidade de Washington, a Universidade do Alaska e a Universidade Estadual de Utah com o objetivo de estudar as características eletrodinâmicas das tempestades elétricas responsáveis pela geração de transientes na alta atmosfera, tais como sprites. O projeto é o segundo no mundo a abordar este tema e o primeiro na região tropical, onde a maior parte das tempestades ocorrem. O estudo será realizado através da adequada instrumentação de cargas úteis a serem lançadas em balões estratosféricos do Centro de Lançamento de Balões Estratosféricos do INPE em Cachoeira Paulista. Os vôos de balão serão acompanhados por registros em tempo real de relâmpagos no solo por câmeras e sensores de radiação. O Brasil através das pesquisas do ELAT já mantém um papel de liderança internacional nas pesquisas sobre raios na região tropical do planeta, como evidenciado pela recente geração do primeiro raio artificial nesta região. Na área de pesquisa com balões estratosféricos, o ELAT possui larga experiência de duas décadas e mais de 20 lançamentos no país e 5 lançamentos no exterior em cooperação com a NASA.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: High-speed Video and Electrical Study of Upward Lightning Triggered by Towers
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This research seeks to address how upward lightning is triggered from tall structures. Existing literature and previous observations suggest that nearby flashes can create conditions favorable for upward leader initiation from tall objects. The objective is to quantify and understand these conditions and determine a triggering flash component responsible for upward leader initiation. A combination of electromagnetic and optical sensors will record upward lightning flashes from multiple towers in Rapid City, South Dakota. Electromagnetic sensors will include electric field meters, fast and slow field change sensors, and two interferometers. Operation of these sensors will be coordinated with high-speed video, tandard definition video, and digital still image cameras. Observations made with these assets will be analyzed along with National Lightning Detection Network (NLDN) and meteorological data (i.e., radar, satellite, thermodynamic sounding and meteorological surface parameters) to determine types of flashes and their properties that affect or are critical for the initiation of upward leaders from tall objects, storm type, region and stage of development during which upward lightning occurs, and the conditions for triggering upward leaders on multiple tall objects during the same flash.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Neste projeto financiado pela NSF, coordenei a aquisição de campo elétrico dos raios ascendentes. Através dos campos elétricos instalados em Rapid City, SD, EUA, pudemos averiguar qual a perturbação gerada pelos raios positivos que iniciam raios ascendentes induzidos.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: High-speed Video and Electrical Study of Upward Lightning Triggered by Towers

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Optical and electromagnetic radiation produced by lightning
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Our plan will be to conduct field campaigns in the summer of 2007 to measure the luminous development of cloud-to-ground and cloud-to-air discharges in correlation with electric field waveforms and an optical radiometer. We will make it possible to obtain video recordings of individual flashes from two or more different locations, and hence permit 3-dimensional reconstruction of the channels and to substantially increase the time-resolution of these measurements. We plan to study both positive and negative flashes in a variety of geographical locations, and we will be able to take full advantage of the data provided by the U.S. National Lightning Detection Network (NLDN) and any LDAR or LMA systems that are operating in the areas of interest. We will focus on the leader and attachment processes, the characteristics of continuing currents, and the factors that influence the formation of large branches and new ground contacts.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Através deste projeto coordenei uma equipe para filmar raios na cidade de Tucson, AZ, EUA. Uma câmera de alta velocidade proveniente do Brasil e outras câmeras padrões da Universidade do Arizona foram utilizadas para observar os raios e comparar as medidas com as feitas no Brasil.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Optical and electromagnetic radiation produced by lightning

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Cloud-to-ground lightning in the Grand Canyon: Attachment and electromagnetic behavior
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This study will provide useful information related to lightning safety in the canyon, and may well provide important new insights for lightning protection related to attachment in mountainous terrain and to tall buildings. The area density of cloud-to-ground (CG) lightning strike observations near the Grand Canyon show strong variations near the canyon rim/walls that are consistent with significant terrain and/or field-enhancement effects. These observations, provided by the U.S. National Lightning Detection Network (NLDN) have a spatial resolution of about 1 km.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Sprite observations from the space shuttle: spectroscopic properties, ELF and VLF signatures and relation to thunderstorms
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: During an upcoming shuttle flight, Tel-Aviv university is scheduled to fly the MEIDEX (Mediterranean Israeli Dust Experiment) payload, which consists of a digital multi-spectral video camera, a wide-FOV camera and digital VCRs for recording the data. The payload will be operated by an Israeli astronaut in cooperation with a ground team located at GSFC. A third team will conduct airborne measurements in the region and sample dust particles. The current date for MEIDEX is summer 2001, for a 16 day mission with 39 degrees inclination, on board the space shuttle Columbia. In order to maximize the scientific yield of MEIDEX, targets of opportunities (TOOs) will be defined, among which the imaging of sprites above active thunderstorms. Sprites will not constitute a primary mission in this shuttle flight, but they will be targeted during night time periods whenever shuttle and experiment resources (astronaut time, attitude maneuver, recording space) can be allocated.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Neste projeto internacional participei fornecendo dados de raios no solo para a observação feita por uma câmera para filmar sprites a bordo do Space Shuttle

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:

Investigar a correlação entre as variações da radiação gama registrada no nível do solo e a ocorrência de tempestades na região de São José dos Campos ? SP.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Two induction techniques using rocket-and-wire systems were applied at the International Center for Natural and Triggered Lightning Studies (CIPRIN) in Brazil: (i) the classical method, which involves a conductive trailing wire connected to the ground and (ii) the altitude method, with an ungrounded wire. The artificial initiation of atmospheric discharges was conducted for the first time in tropical latitudes. The 4 campaigns analyzed in this work occurred during the summers of 2000 to 2003, resulting in 41 rocket flights with success rates of 45% and 27% for the classical and the altitude techniques, respectively. Coaxial shunts, an optical sensor, electric field antennas and a high speed camera were used for characterizing the current waveforms of the classical strokes. Simultaneous results on current, luminosity and electric field, accompanied by high-speed camera images were obtained for the first time for an altitude flash. In addition, the peak currents of the strokes were determined using data from the shunts and compared to measurements from magnetic cards. The Brazilian Integrated Network (BIN), ground-based sensors that cover the southeastern area of Brazil, detected 54% of the triggered flashes. Compared to both artificial lightning observations performed in other countries and natural strokes detected by the BIN during the induced events, there was a tendency for peak currents to be generally higher for triggered lightning at CIPRIN . Moreover, the current pulses of the induced strokes observed in Brazil were faster than pulses measured in other sites. The higher peak currents and faster pulses observed at CIPRIN resulted in similar values of charge transferred per stroke compared to data obtained by other sites. However, more triggering experiments at CIPRIN are needed to provide better statistical results.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Este trabalho visa obter uma melhor compreensão da evolução da corrente continua de raios naturais através de filmagens obtidas por uma câmera de alta resolução temporal. Estudos anteriores analisaram algumas medidas diretas de corrente em raios artificiais (induzidos) ou medidas remotas de campo elétrico em descargas naturais. Deseja-se com esta nova técnica analisar a evolução da forma da corrente contínua e também dos parâmetros das componentes-M associadas. Para tal desenvolvemos um software em IDL que analisa os pixels das imagens e levanta um gráfico de luminosidade versus tempo. Sabendo-se que a luminosidade emitida pelo raio é diretamente proporcional à sua corrente, obtivemos os parâmetros propostos.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This paper reports some cloud-to-ground (CG) negative flashes parameters that are accurate and may be useful in lighting protection. Some of these parameters are: multiplicity, number of ground contact points per flash, number of strikes per ground contact, occurrence frequency of continuing current in return strokes. The present study was based on 314 high-speed camera records (1,000 frames/sec.) conjugated with RINDAT (Integrated National Lightning Detection Network) real-time and reprocessed data for most of the events. Flashes from 27 thunderstorms were observed from two observational sites located in the cities of São José dos Campos and Cachoeira Paulista, both in Paraíba Valley (São Paulo State). Based on RINDAT data, we could classify a subgroup of 233 CG flashes as negatives, which were used to generate these results. 80% of all recorded flashes were 10-40 km far from the camera and also from two RINDAT antennas, located very close to the sites. The percentage of single flashes was 20%. 51% struck the ground in two or more places that were separated by tens of meters or more. The average multiplicity found was 3.8 strokes per flash and the average number of ground contact points was 1.7. Based on these two values we obtained the average number of strikes per ground contact, 2.2. Considering the geometric mean value of interstroke time interval (61 ms), we can say that in average if a ground contact is struck once it will be struck again after 61 ms. Some of the estimates, like the average number of strikes per ground contact, were only possible to be obtained due to the simultaneous accurate stroke counting and accurate visualization of their channels given by a high-speed camera. With this methodology it was also possible to calculate the detection efficiency of the lightning detection network (87% for the region studied) and use it to correct the ground-flash density maps.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: A study of cloud-to-ground lightning characteristics based on high-speed camera observations of 455 flashes related to 40 thunderstorms is presented. The Brazilian Lightning Location Network (RINDAT) was used to calculate the polarity and the distance of the flashes to the camera. In some cases, a fast electric field flat antenna was also used to calculate the time difference between strokes on a microsecond-scale. Some general features of the data set are briefly presented. This paper is focused on two specific characteristics observed in video records with frame a rate of 1,000 frames/s: (i) six strokes presenting two ground terminations that were simultaneously connected for some milliseconds, (ii) and a high number of continuing current occurrences with durations less than 10 ms.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Abstract - Data from the Brazilian Integrated Lightning Detection Network (RINDAT) from 1999 to 2004 were used to study the long-term characteristics of the lightning activity in the region covered by the states of São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, Minas Gerais, Paraná, Goías and Espirito Santo. The data were reprocessed to avoid the well known limitations in real time data, and model corrected to overcome the limitations of the network in terms of flash detection efficiency. The following characteristics were studied: flash density, percentage positive flashes, negative multiplicity and peak current of negative and positive flashes. The flash density was corrected by a model considering the flash detection efficiency of individual sensors, incorporating the variations of the network configuration through the period of study. Surprisingly, the map of flash density shows that the dominant feature responsible for the region of largest flash density, the city of São Paulo and surrounding areas, is the urban effect. In this region, a maximum of 17 flashes.km-1.year-1 is found in the east region of the city of São Paulo, a value larger than the peak value of about 15 flashes.km-1.year-1 observed in United States in the state of Florida. Similar enhancements in the flash density were observed near other large urban areas like Campinas and Belo Horizonte. Other region with a large flash density was identified in the South of state of Rio de Janeiro, with no apparent explanation. The other lightning characteristics also show significant variations. These variations, however, are not clearly related to any particular feature and merit more investigation.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Comparison among lightning data obtained by different lightning location systems and a fast electric field antenna in southeastern Brazil

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: A comparison of lightning data observed in two different days of February 2005, obtained by different lightning location systems is presented. The complete data set was shown to be a unique opportunity not only to validate the RINDAT data, but also to better understand the differences among the different techniques of lightning detection. Apart from the correlation between the results given by these different systems, parameters of the discharges given by some of the location systems will be compared with the fast E-field recordings.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The aim of this work is to study some properties of continuing currents and M-components in natural lightning by means of a high speed camera. The literature presents similar studies using only direct measurements of the channel base current in triggered-lightning flashes and remote electric field measurements of close natural discharges. In this work we analyze the waveform of the continuing currents and obtain parameters of the M-components associated. For this purpose, we developed a computational algorithm using IDL that analyses the pixels of the images obtained by the high-speed camera and plots a graph showing luminosity versus time. As the luminosity in the channel is directly proportional to the current of the lightning, some statistics are done in terms of continuing current waveform types and M-component occurrence.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Watching the meteorological balloons customarily launched from our city, we wondered how we could develop an experiment to allow our students to effectively gather data about the low atmosphere and at the same time keep our limited financial budget. When you hear about atmospheric balloons, you usually think about balloons with large envelopes of nylon or mylar with payloads between 1 or 10 kg. They ascend to very high altitudes, have a data radio transmitter, and are not recoverable. This setup would be too expensive for us. In order to keep the cost low, the payload containing the data recorded had to be recovered, and therefore, the balloon must not go tens of kilometers away. Based on some estimates of ascension speed for small balloons and probable horizontal wind intensities, we decided that in order to easily recover the payload we had to limit its ascension to about 2 km high. At this altitude, the payload would have to be released from the balloon by means of a timer. Our envelope consists of four latex 1-m diameter balloons (the biggest we could get) of the kind used at children's parties. Altogether they had a net buoyancy capacity of 500 g, enough to lift a mini tape recorder, batteries and simple electronic circuits that transform the atmosphere temperature into sound frequency.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Possibility of high peak current strokes followed by long continuing current in ground flashes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We consider the possibility of existence of high peak current strokes followed by long continuing current in ground flashes, a combination that would offer an appreciable threat to protection systems. The observation of 454 negative strokes followed by continuing currents from 4 ms to 542 ms reveals that negative strokes combining both high peak current and long continuing current are very improbable to occur. However this possibility is real for positive strokes. This study was performed using a high-speed camera (1,000 frames/s), a slow electric field flat antenna and data from the Brazilian Lightning Location Network (RINDAT). All data was GPS synchronized allowing the matching and the comparison between stroke peak current and initial electric field peak with the duration of continuing current. The detection efficiency for stroke followed by very-short, short and long continuing currents were respectively 62.1, 57.4 and 35.7%.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Geophysical Research Abstracts

AUTORES.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: SABA, M. M. F.;SABA, M;Saba, Marcelo M. F.;Saba, Marcelo Magalhães Fares;SABA, MARCELO M.F.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: From analysis of digital high-speed video records of 233 negative cloud-to-ground (CG) lightning flashes associated to 27 thunderstorms in southeastern Brazil, various lightning properties have been determined. The analysis of the video records showed that although 20% of them were single-stroke flashes and the average number of strokes per flash was 3.8, a significant variation was observed in these parameters from storm to storm. In a smaller subset containing 138 flashes, 70 (51%) had multiple terminations on ground. 138 flashes produced 235 different strike points; therefore, the average number of strike points per CG flash was 1.70. Considering that in this study the missing of strokes is practically negligible, we can say from the average multiplicity and from the average number of strike points per flash, that each ground contact point is, in average, struck 2.2 times. 608 time intervals between strokes of 186 negative multiple-stroke flashes presented a geometric mean value of 61 ms. A strong positive correlation between the number of subsequent strokes in a flash and the flash minimum duration may indicate that some processes concerning the time requisite for the channel decay and for the positive leader in the cloud to provide more charges for the next stroke, do not permit multiple strokes occur under a certain minimum time duration. Flash and stroke detection efficiency of the Brazilian lightning location system is discussed.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Probability distribution for natural downward negative lightning parameters based on accurate-stroke-count studies

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: New data collected in southeast Brazil by means of a digital high-speed camera (1,000 frames/sec) related to natural negative downward lightning is presented in terms of probability distributions. Together with other selected studies, a comparison is done with Berger?s data, which has been the basis for standards on lightning protection. The parameters of downward negative lightning discussed in this study are: (a) continuing current duration, (b) time intervals between strokes, (c) number of strokes per flash and (d) total flash duration. The Brazilian Integrated Lightning Detection Network was used in order to identify the polarity of the observed flashes. A total of 233 natural downward negative flashes related to 27 different thunderstorm days were recorded from two different sites in Paraíba Valley (São Paulo State) and are analyzed here. This comparison of natural lightning parameters was done based on those ?accurate-strokecount studies?, as defined by Rakov and Huffines [Journal of Applied Meteorology, 42, 2003]. The results of those selected studies are reliable in terms of stroke identification and therefore very useful to estimate those parameters (a-d) of natural negative cloudto- ground lightning.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The aim of this work is to obtain characteristics of the preliminary breakdown (PB) pulses in cloud-to-ground flashes using a high-speed imaging system and electric field measurements. These two method combined facilitates the identification of the pulse, which is related to a increase in the luminosity at the region from which the flash is originated. 98 PB pulses from first order strokes were analysed. Correlation analysis between the time from the pulse to the return stroke and its electric field peak (normalized to 100 km) were obtained. In a few cases (7) it was possible to observe the stepped leader in the images generated by the high-speed imaging system. The descending speeds of the leader were also determined for these cases.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: O objetivo deste trabalho é determinar a velocidade de descida do líder escalonado de relâmpagos a partir dos registros realizados através de uma câmera de alta resolução temporal. Mais de 500 raios foram filmados em São José dos Campos, SP, utilizando uma câmera MotionScope® PCI, fabricada pela RedLake e configurada para gravar 1000 imagens por segundo, durante os verões de 2003 a 2006. A partir destes vídeos foram selecionadas 50 descargas de retorno em que o líder escalonado foi registrado, sendo 48 descargas negativas e 2 positivas. A partir da distância do raio à câmera obtida pela RINDAT - Rede Integrada Nacional de Detecção de Descargas Atmosféricas e da analise de cada vídeo quadro a quadro, obtivemos a velocidade em duas dimensões do líder a cada milissegundo, bem como a sua velocidade média ao longo de toda a trajetória nuvem-solo. Na literatura, existe apenas um registro da velocidade do líder de um relâmpago positivo. A média aritmética das velocidades descritas pelos líderes negativos foi igual a 3,2 × 105 m/s. Para os dois líderes positivos observados obtivemos velocidades médias iguais a 2,5 × 105 e 8,8 × 105 m/s, ou seja, uma acima e outra abaixo do valor médio para os negativos. Mais de 90% dos 48 casos negativos apresentaram velocidades inferiores a 5,5 × 105 m/s e quase 50% situaram-se entre 2,0 × 105 e 3,0 × 105 m/s. Apesar deste trabalho ser o segundo a apresentar estimativas precisas da velocidade de líderes positivos, os dados obtidos até o momento ainda não permitem determinar se estes possuem alguma tendência a comportar-se de forma distinta em relação aos negativos.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In this study we analyze strokes following a new channel to ground in 118 multiple channel flashes observed in southeastern Brazil. Some characteristics are presented, such as: (i) the pattern in the initiation of long-continuing current; (ii) the electric field peak value of new-channel strokes followed by long-continuing current.

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Produção e Distribuição de Energia Elétrica

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Using a high-speed camera (1,000 frames/s), slow and fast electric field flat antennas and data from the Brazilian Lightning Location Network (RINDAT) we study the peak current and interstroke time interval preceding lightning strokes that are followed by continuing current. The observation of nearly 500 negative strokes followed by continuing currents from 4 ms to 542 ms reveals that negative strokes combining both high peak current and long continuing current are very improbable to occur although this possibility is real for positive strokes. The detection efficiency for strokes that are followed by short or long continuing currents is lower. A relation between the duration of the continuing current and the duration of the previous interstroke interval is also presented.

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Produção e Distribuição de Energia Elétrica

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The aim of this work is to obtain some characteristics of the preliminary breakdown (PB) pulses for negative cloud-to-ground flashes. We present the correlation between the electric field peak of first strokes and subsequent new-channel strokes and the time interval from the beginning of the PB and the stroke event. For this purpose we employed a high-speed observation system (with a time resolution of 1000 frames per second), electric field measurements (flat plate antenna) and data from the Brazilian Lightning Location System - RINDAT, all them synchronized with GPS. All measurements and observations were made in S. José dos Campos (45.864°W; 23.215°S), Brazil. The beginning of the PB pulses could be determined both in the electric field data and in the high-speed video recorded (in which it is possible to observe a low intensity light emission from the cloud), a very difficult task in the absence of the images. The electric field peak values of the strokes were all normalized to 100 km, based on the location solution given by RINDAT. An amount of 30 first strokes and 16 subsequent new-channel strokes, all from the same day (March 23rd, 2005), were analyzed, and their data (PB to stroke interval versus the inverse of the stroke electric field peak) were plotted. The graph obtained for first strokes showed a linear relationship (correlation coefficient: 0.85). No correlation was found for subsequent new-channel strokes.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: A new performance evaluation of the Brazilian lightning location system(RINDAT) based on high-speed camera observations of natural negative ground flashes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The lightning detection network data is very useful in many activities of the society. Power utilities in general, weather "nowcast", agriculture can be cited as some examples. It is important to know the performance of the network for an appropriate use of this data. The network performance is usually described by two parameters: (a) the Detection Efficiency (DE) and the (b) Location Accuracy (LA). The DE means the percentage of strokes (or flashes) that are detected by the network and LA means the error level on the location given by the network.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: From analysis of digital high-speed video records of hundreds of cloud-to-ground continuing current in southeastern Brazil, various continuing current properties have been determined for long continuing current. The topics analyzed in this work are: percentage of flashes containing long continuing current; containing one or more than one long continuing current, duration distribution, effect of stroke order, first strokes followed by continuing current in single and multiple flashes, percentage of flashes terminated by continuing current, occurrence in new channels, duration of previous interstroke interval versus continuing current duration, relation between lightning return stroke peak current and following continuing current, detection of strokes followed by continuing current. Several properties are compared to other results from past studies done in different regions of the world. All flashes were recorded with a Redlake MotionScope 8000S digital high-speed camera (1,000 frames per second, 1.0 ms of exposure time and 2.0 sec of recording time) synchronized with GPS. The frame rate used avoids the usual missing of strokes in studies that use standard video cameras (30 frames per second). The Brazilian Lightning Location System covered the areas of observation (south and southeastern Brazil) was used to determine the polarity of the observed lightning flashes.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In this report, we will summarize the characteristics of downward-propagating, positive leaders that were recorded with high-speed video cameras. We will also report the existence of negative recoil leaders (RLs) that appear during the leader propagation toward ground. The RLs reveal branching structures that are not usually recorded when using conventional photography or video cameras. The characteristics of the RLs will be described and compared to previously observed features of +CG flashes.

AUTORES.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: SABA, M. M. F.;SABA, M;Saba, Marcelo M. F.;Saba, Marcelo Magalhães Fares;SABA, MARCELO M.F.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Continuing current is a continuous mode of charge transfer to ground in a flash. It is responsible for most serious lightning damage associated with thermal effects and the extent to which the continuing current contributes to the total positive charge lowered to earth is large. 74% of the positive flashes analyzed contained at least one long CC event (longer than 40 ms). This percentage is less than 50% for negative flashes. The ?exclusion zone? (inexistence of high peak current strokes followed by long CC) observed for negative strokes in a previous paper was not observed for positive strokes. Long continuing currents following high peak current strokes are present in nearly 50% of positive strokes. Waveshapes of continuing currents of natural positive flashes are studied using a computational algorithm that analyzes the pixels of the images obtained by a high-speed camera and plots luminosity-versus-time. Tower measurements have shown that during the continuing current phase of the flash the luminosity of the channel is directly proportional to the current that flows through it. Using this information it was possible to infer the continuing current waveshape for natural positive flashes and classify them into four types. Contrary to the results presented in former studies for triggered flashes and for negative CG flashes, we have not observed some waveshape types in the positive CC dataset. The average number of M-components per CC found in this study was 9.0 for positive CG lightning, while for negative cases it was 5.5. This difference may be related to the very distinctive temporal distribution in each case.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: High-speed video recordings will be used to illustrate the luminous development of positive and negative lightning discharges from cloud-to-ground (CG) and from ground-to-cloud. The estimated peak currents of positive and negative CG flashes, as measured by the U.S. National Lightning Detection Network (NLDN), will be reviewed together with the NLDN performance, the multiplicity of strokes, and the number of different ground contacts in Arizona, Florida, Texas-Oklahoma, and the Great Plains.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Halos: a solution to the sprite polarity paradox

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: IAGA 2009 Proceedings

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: C.T.R. Wilsons explanation for sprite initiation in the mesosphere by lightning in the troposphere is independent of the polarity of the parent lightning. Yet in thousands of published ground-based observations of sprites, only three have been clearly associated with ground flashes with negative polarity. This finding is however inconsistent with ELF measurements of charge moments, showing that typically 10% of supercritical values are negative in polarity. ISUAL satellite measurements in the Earths limb have exposed a population of halos that is a substantially larger fraction of total TLEs (sprites+halos) than in the earlier ground-based measurements. ELF measurements from Nagycenk, Hungary for more than one hundreds ISUAL-identified halos show a predominant negative polarity in the parent lightning with a range of charge moments from 300-1200 C-km. Halo brightness measured by ISUAL is positively correlated with the vertical charge moment, consistent with theoretical predictions based on impact excitation of nitrogen for halo production. The polarity asymmetry in TLE production by positive and negative ground flashes appears to resolve the original sprite polarity paradox. The physical reasons for the differences in positive and negative flashes deserve further clarification.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: From the analysis of digital high-speed videos and electric field records of two flashes, some relationships are presented between the channel luminosity preceding the occurrence of the luminosity pulse and the characteristics of the related electric field signature. Some M components may produce Efield signatures very similar to those produced by subsequent return strokes if the preceding luminosity of channel flash is very faint. These M components may be detected by LLS. If the channel luminosity is high, that is, if the continuing current flowing through it is high, then the E-field signature is different from the signature of a subsequent return stroke. The luminosity intensity preceding each M component along with its 10-90% risetime, estimated peak current and peak E-field are presented.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: High-speed video observations of positive lightning flashes to ground

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: AGU - The Meeting of the Americas
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: AGU - The Meeting of the Americas

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Although positive lightning flashes to ground are not as frequent as negative flashes, their large amplitudes and destructive characteristics make understanding their parameters an important issue. This study summarizes the characteristics of 103 positive cloud-to-ground (+CG) flashes that have been recorded using high-speed video cameras (up to 11,800 frames per second) in three countries together with time-correlated data provided by lightning location systems (LLS). A large fraction of the +CG flashes (81%) produced just a single-stroke, and the average multiplicity was 1.2 strokes per flash. All the subsequent strokes in multiple-stroke +CG flashes created a new ground termination except one. The geometric mean of 21 interstroke time-intervals was 94 ms, which is about 1.5 times larger the average interstroke interval in negative CG flashes (~ 60 ms). 75% of the +CG flashes contained at least one long continuing current (LCC) ≥ 40 ms, and this percentage is significantly larger than in the negative flashes that produce LCCs (approximately 30%). The median estimated peak current, (Ip) for 116 positive strokes that created new ground terminations was 39.4 kA. Positive strokes with a large Ip were usually followed by a LCC, and both of these parameters are threats in lightning protection. The characteristics presented here include the multiplicities of strokes and ground contacts, the percentage of single-stroke flashes, the average interstroke time-interval, the durations of the continuing current, and the distributions of Ip, the total flash durations, and the 2-D leader speeds.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Ovo no Alvo is a challenging competition that simulates the strategies and the scientific thinking usually required in space science missions.
Participants are asked to protect an egg from a second story drop to keep it from smashing when it hits the ground! Accuracy of the drop ? minimizing the weight of the protective device ? and minimizing the number of components in the protective device ? are all factors in determining in determining the success of the project. Once a year, more than 500 students and their teachers group together to elaborate the protective device (spacecraft) that will protect an egg (astronaut) in a precise and safe landing. As in space missions, the spacecraft must be as light as possible and as simple as possible. Several important physical concepts and scientific methodology are involved in this competition. This work summarizes some past experiences and achievements.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: A Low-cost Sounding Balloon Experiment: a High-school Research Project

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: AGU Fall Meeting

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Watching the meteorological balloons customarily launched from our city, we wondered how we could develop an experiment to allow our students to effectively gather data about the low atmosphere and at the same time keep our limited financial budget. When you hear about atmospheric balloons, you usually think about balloons with large envelopes of nylon or mylar with payloads between 1 or 10 kg. They ascend to very high altitudes, have a data radio transmitter, and are not recoverable. This setup would be too expensive for us. In order to keep the cost low, the payload containing the data recorded had to be recovered, and therefore, the balloon must not go tens of kilometers away. Based on some estimates of ascension speed for small balloons and probable horizontal wind intensities, we decided that in order to easily recover the payload we had to limit its ascension to about 3 km high. At this altitude, the payload would have to be released from the balloon by means of a timer. Our envelope consists of four latex 1-m diameter balloons (the biggest we could get) of the kind used at children's parties. Altogether they had a net buoyancy capacity of 500 g, enough to lift a mini digital camera, a sound recorder, batteries and simple electronic circuits that transform the atmosphere temperature into sound frequency. The scientific and educational achievements of this challenging high-school research project will be presented.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Rockets and Aerial Photography: a High-school Research Project

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: AGU Fall Meeting

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Building and launching a rocket was a great opportunity to learn more deeply several topics of high-school physics. Pressure, action and reaction, speed and acceleration, terminal velocity, air drag and several other physics concepts and laws were explored during the building and launching of an amateur experimental rocket that was also used for aerial photography. This project was also a great opportunity to experience the excitement of scientific research.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: High-speed video observations of positive lightning flashes to ground
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: High-speed video observations of positive lightning flashes to ground

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 30th International Conference on Lightning Protection

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Although positive lightning flashes to ground are not as frequent as negative flashes, their large amplitudes and destructive characteristics make understanding their parameters an important issue. This study summarizes the characteristics of 103 positive cloud-to-ground (+CG) flashes that have been recorded using high-speed video cameras (up to 11,800 frames per second) in three countries together with time-correlated data provided by lightning location systems (LLS). A large fraction of the +CG flashes (81%) produced just a single-stroke, and the average multiplicity was 1.2 strokes per flash. All the subsequent strokes in multiple-stroke +CG flashes created a new ground termination except one. The geometric mean of 21 interstroke time-intervals was 94 ms, which is about 1.5 times larger the average interstroke interval in negative CG flashes (~ 60 ms). 75% of the +CG flashes contained at least one long continuing current (LCC) ≥ 40 ms, and this percentage is significantly larger than in the negative flashes that produce LCCs (approximately 30%). The median estimated peak current, (Ip) for 116 positive strokes that created new ground terminations was 39.4 kA. Positive strokes with a large Ip were usually followed by a LCC, and both of these parameters are threats in lightning protection. The characteristics presented here include the multiplicities of strokes and ground contacts, the percentage of single-stroke flashes, the average interstroke time-interval, the durations of the continuing current, and the distributions of Ip, the total flash durations, and the 2-D leader speeds.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: The CHUVA Lightning Mapping Campaign

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: AGU Fall Meeting 2011

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The primary science objective for the CHUVA lightning mapping campaign is to combine measurements of total lightning activity, lightning channel mapping, and detailed information on the locations of cloud charge regions of thunderstorms with the planned observations of the CHUVA (Cloud processes of tHe main precipitation systems in Brazil: A contribUtion to cloud resolVing modeling and to the GPM (GlobAl Precipitation Measurement) field campaign. The lightning campaign takes place during the CHUVA intensive observation period October-December 2011 in the vicinity of São Luiz do Paraitinga with Brazilian, US, and European government, university and industry participants. Total lightning measurements that can be provided by ground-based regional 2-D and 3-D total lightning mapping networks coincident with overpasses of the Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission Lightning Imaging Sensor (LIS) and the SEVIRI (Spinning Enhanced Visible and Infrared Imager) on the Meteosat Second Generation satellite in geostationary earth orbit will be used to generate proxy data sets for the next generation US and European geostationary satellites. Proxy data, which play an important role in the pre-launch mission development and in user readiness preparation, are used to develop and validate algorithms so that they will be ready for operational use quickly following the planned launch of the GOES-R Geostationary Lightning Mapper (GLM) in 2015 and the Meteosat Third Generation Lightning Imager (LI) in 2017. To date there is no well-characterized total lightning data set coincident with the imagers. Therefore, to take the greatest advantage of this opportunity to collect detailed and comprehensive total lightning data sets, test and validate multi-sensor nowcasting applications for the monitoring, tracking, warning, and prediction of severe and high impact weather, and to advance our knowledge of thunderstorm physics, extensive measurements from lightning mapping networks will be collected

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Upward Lightning in Brazil

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 22nd International Lightning Detection Conference

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Observations of upward lightning from tall objects have been reported since 1939. Interest in this subject has grown recently, some of it because of the rapid expansion of wind power generation. Also, with the increasing number of tall buildings and towers, there will be a corresponding increase in the number of upward lightning flashes from these structures. Reports from recent field observations are beginning to address the nature of upward lightning initiation, but much still needs to be learned. Examples are studies of upward lightning from towers in winter thunderstorms in Japan (Wang and Takagi, 2010; and Lu et al., 2009) and summer thunderstorms in Europe (Miki et al., 2005; Flache et al., 2008; and Diendorfer et al., 2009; Zhou et al., 2011) and in North America (Mazur and Ruhnke, 2011; Hussein et al., 2011; Warner, 2011, and Warner et al., 2011). This paper describes a field campaign to study upward lightning for the first time in Brazil. A combination of high-speed video and standard definition video were used to record upward lightning flashes from multiple towers in Sao Paulo, Brazil, a city located in southeastern Brazil with a population over 10 million people, an average elevation of around 800 meters above sea level, and a flash density of 15 flashes/km2/year. Observations made with these assets were analyzed along with BrasilDAT Lightning Detection Network and a lightning mapping array (LMA).

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Presence of Continuing Current in Negative Cloud-to-Ground Flashes

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 22nd International Lightning Detection Conference

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In this paper we study the presence of continuing currents(CC) in negative flashes. The database used in this study is the largest among those reported in the literature. The combined techniques of observation such as electric field measurements and high resolution videos, increased the capacity to discriminate the presence of CC in flashes. A total of 971 flashes that occurred between 2003 and 2011 were selected for this study. We analyzed the occurrence of CC in terms of its duration and its relation to the previous interstroke time interval, the peak current of the discharge that contains it, the flash multiplicity, the influence of new channels, the order in which the discharge occurs, and the detection efficiency of the lightning location network (BrasilDat). The results allowed us to better understand the usual conditions that favor the occurrence of continuing current: a shorter interstroke interval preceding the continuing current, a lower peak current stroke initiating a continuing current and that continuing currents usually occur in a subsequent stroke which follows the same channel used by the previous strokes. The occurrence of long continuing current usually ends a flash or promotes another stroke in the same channel indicating that long continuing currents can be an important factor in establishing a channel. Long continuing current which have lower current intensity usually occurs in flashes with higher multiplicity. Long continuing current with higher current intensity usually ends the flash causing a lower multiplicity lightning flash. Strokes containing long continuing current were less detected when compared to those containing currents with shorter duration or without continuing currents

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: High-Speed Video and Electric Field Observations of Type Beta-2 Leaders in Negative Lightning: A Manifestation of Recoil Leaders Initiated Inside the Cloud?

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 22nd International Lightning Detection Conference

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Schonland et al. (Progressive lightning, 6, Proc. Roy. Soc. (London), A168, 455-469, 1938), in their seminal streak camera studies of lightning, have identified four events of a peculiar type of negative stepped leader that they termed ?β2?, a ?rather rare variant of the type β leader? and in it ?the second and slower stage of the leader is associated with the appearance of one or more fast dart streamers, which travel rapidly down from the cloud along the previously formed track and cease when they have caught up with the slower leader-tip?. During two different campaigns between 2007 and 2011 in Tucson, Arizona, USA, and in São José dos Campos, São Paulo, Brazil, we recorded seven downward leaders that fit in the type β2 description given by Schonland et al. (1938). All cases occurred between about 5 and 32 km from a high-speed camera that was operating at 4000 frames per second and three of them could also have their electric field changes measured. All the ?dart streamers? that we observed had speeds between 106 and 107 m s-1, in agreement with previous observations of recoil leaders (RLs). Also, during the development of the three cases whose electric field change data was available it was possible to identify a sequence of microsecond-scale pulses preceding the development of the Considering the similarities in the optical and electric field signatures of both phenomena, we propose that the type β2 negative leaders are the visible manifestation of the development of RLs that were initiated inside the cloud and propagate below the cloud-base during the development of a bipolar, bidirectional leader that precedes a lightning flash to ground. The RLs are initiated in and propagate through channels that were previously ionized by the in-cloud positive portion of a bidirectional leader, eventually connecting to one of its active branches. When they do an intense return pulse of luminosity that optically appears as the dart streamer reported by

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Triggered Upward Lightning from Towers in Rapid City, South Dakota

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 22nd International Lightning Detection Conference

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Recent research efforts have shown that nearby flashes can trigger upward lightning from tall towers (e.g., Wang and Takagi, 2010; Mazur and Ruhnke, 2011; Warner, 2011, Warner et al., 2011, and Zhou et al., 2011). Findings from these studies suggest that these lightning-triggered upward lightning (LTUL) flashes are more common with summer thunderstorms, whereas self-initiated upward lightning (SIUL) flashes, where an upward leader initiates from a tall object without nearby preceding flash activity, favor less active winter storms. For LTUL, a preceding positive cloud-to-ground (+CG) flash appears to be the dominant triggering flash type resulting in upward positive leaders (UPLs). However, the specific triggering flash component and mechanism has yet to be fully quantified. In this paper, we characterize the triggering flash types, components and mechanisms responsible for LTUL during summer thunderstorms in Rapid City, South Dakota. We also characterize favorable storm types and regions.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Characteristics of Upward Leaders from Tall Towers

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 22nd International Lightning Detection Conference

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Although scientific literature contains observed characteristics and behavior of upward lightning (e.g., Rakov and Uman, 2003, Ch 6), the integration of high-speed digital cameras into continued research on the topic has allowed for new insight and comparison (e.g., Diendorfer et al., 2003; Flache et al., 2008; Lu et al., 2009; Mazur and Ruhnke, 2011; Wang and Takagi, 2010; Zhou et al., 2011; Hussein et al., 2011; Warner, 2011, and Warner et al., 2011) In this paper, we present characteristics and behaviors of upward positive leaders (UPLs) from 10 tall towers in Rapid City, South Dakota observed using high-speed cameras and other optical sensors along with coordinated electric field instrumentation. All observations were made in the summer thunderstorm season (Apr ? Sep).

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: An experimental study of leaders initiated by single and advanced (ESE) lightning rods

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 27th International Conference on Lightning Protection

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Specifically designed to allow testing to be conducted on both naturally occurring and triggered lightning strikes, the Cachoeira Paulista facility was built in 1998 on the initiative of INDELEC, the University of Toulouse in France, Hydro-Quebec (IREQ) in Canada and the Brazilian universities of Campinas and San José Dos Campos in Sao Paulo state. The main on-going test involves comparing single rod and advanced lightning conductors, so-called Early Streamer Emission (ESE) rod. An apparatus carrying the measuring instruments and lightning devices under test is subjected to strikes triggered at altitude, the final point of impact being determined by the discharge itself. The investigation techniques, together with the main results of the previous campaigns are set out herein.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Bipolar cloud-to-ground flashes observations

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 31st International Conference on Lightning Protection

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Bipolar lightning is defined as a lightning event where the current waveform exhibits a polarity reversal within the same flash. There are very few reported cases of cloud-to-ground (CG) bipolar flashes using only one channel in the literature. Reports on this type of bipolar flashes are not common due to the fact that in order to confirm that currents of both polarities follow the same channel to the ground one necessarily needs video records. This study presents two clear observations of single-channel, bipolar CG flashes. High-speed video and electric field measurements observations are used and analyzed. Based on the video images obtained and based on previous observations of positive CG flashes with high-speed cameras [1-3] we will suggest that recoil leaders occurring after the positive stroke may generate a subsequent stroke with an opposite polarity.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Electric field waveforms of M components in negative and positive ground flashes

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 31st International Conference on Lightning Protection

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: There has been some discussion concerning the nature of luminosity pulses observed during the continuing currents of positive cloud-to-ground flashes. It still undefined whether or not these pulses can be considered M components when compared to similar events observed in negative flashes. In the present paper we expand this discussion by analyzing electric field waveforms associated with channel luminosity enhancements of both negative and positive ground flashes. Typically, negative M components are preceded by high-frequency pulses similar to those that can are associated to recoil leaders that are visible below cloud base. On the other hand, luminous processes in positive flashes (similar to M components) did not present a particularly common electric field signature, and no pulses could be positively correlated to their inception inside the cloud. We believe that this polarity asymmetry favors previous theories on the production of negative M components according to the bidirectional leader model. The distinctive features of the positive M components suggest that they are related to different processes.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Continuing Current Intensity in Positive Ground Flashes

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 31st International Conference on Lightning Protection

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The highest directly measured lightning currents and the largest charge transfers to ground are thought to be associated with positive lightning. Brook at al. [1] for one positive lightning in a winter storm in Japan, inferred a charge transfer in excess of 300 coulomb (C) during de first 4ms. But charge transfers to beyond 3000C were reported from direct current measurements, by Miyake et al.[1] for positive winter lightning in Japan. Positive strokes may have high peak currents followed by long continuing current (CC), and thus combine these two threatening features for lightning protection. Although positive flashes are usually less frequent than negative lightning, the special characteristics of their CC make the understanding of positive lightning an important issue. Positive lightning were recorded in southeastern Brazil during the summers of 2009-2011. This study presents some CC intensity estimates obtained from an electric field capacitive antenna. Most CC intensities were much higher than the usual intensity values of CC in negative flashes.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Implantação de uma rede de monitoramento do campo elétrico atmosférico no Vale do Paraíba

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Medidas simultâneas de radiação gama, precipitação e de atividade elétrica atmosférica em São José dos Campos - SP
